div.head:
EmblemeEmblem 6. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Sowesow your gold in the white foliated earth.

lg.l: Rusticks their seed to th' fertile earth committ,
When with their harrows they have made it fitt:
The Sophi thus their golden seed due sowe
In foliated earth as white as Snow:
This method well observed, and you'le behold,
As in a glasse, by wheat, your budding gold.

div.head: Discourse 6.
div.ab:
A City sayth plato subsiste not by physician and physician, but by physician and
husbandman, that is, men of divers functions, but here mentions the husbandman
and physician first, because their worke are very conspicuous in the imitation,
emendation, and perfection of nature: for they both take a naturall subject,
in which they attending to art add some certaine things necessary being wanting,
or allso remove those things which are superfluous: soe that the art of both may
(as medicine by Hippocrates) be defined by the addition of defect, and subtract
tion of superfluity: for what dos the husbandman more than add ploughing, ridging
furrowing, harrowing, dunging or manuring, sowing, et. to land left by nature, that
is, commit the increase and good successe to nature, which administreth the heat
of the Sunne, and raine, and multiplyes the seeds by them, and promotes them to
standing corne soon after to be reaped: in the meane time whilst the herbe is
springing the husbandman weeds out thistles and all impediments, gashes
the corne being ripe, takes away things superfluous from it being reaped, namely
straw, chaffe, and such other things: Soe allso a physician (as allso a Chymist in
a different respect)Teatheth how to praserve praesent health to many body, being
wanting to recover it by severall remedyes, takes away the morbificke cause,
cures the disease, assuageth symptoms, abates superfluous blood by opening
a veyne, being wanting restores it by apointing good order of dyet, evacua
ates noxious humors by purgation, and soe imitates, supplyes, and amends
nature a thousand ways by the works of the understanding and art; which
being notorious, Chymicall things are rather to be considered by us: for Chy
mistry doth first declare the operations of agriculture by its secret bounds
and wayes of operating: Husbandman have land, wherein to sow seed, soe allso
the Chymists: they have dung wherewith to manure their ground, soe
allso these, without which nothing could be done, nor any successe expected:
They have seed, the multiplication of which they desire: if Chymists
had not the like, they would (as Lully sayth) imitate the painter, that
endeavoures to expresse the fate of a certaine man, whome hee had never
seen, nor the image of him: Husbandman expect raine, and heat of the
Sunne, soe allso doe the Chymists truely administer heat convenient to
their worke, and raine: I need say noe more: X Chymistry is exactly parallell to agriculture, and its deputy,
which in all things expreesseth its offices, but under a most absolute alle- <lb break="no/>gory-----
